title: 112_s1713
content: The "U.S.A. AAA Credit Restoration Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes an amendment to Title 31. Section 3101(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit the face amount of obligations issued under this chapter and guaranteed by the US Government. The Secretary must provide an estimate of the public debt limit to Congress on the same day the President submits the budget. The Secretary must estimate the public debt limit increase needed based on federal revenues and expenditures. This estimate must be published in the Federal Register on the same day as the submission to Congress. The term 'joint resolution' refers to a resolution introduced within a specific timeframe disapproving the Secretary's authority to increase the debt limit. Expedited consideration in the House of Representatives is also outlined. Expedited consideration in the House of Representatives requires the Speaker to reconvene the House within two days of receiving certification. If a joint resolution is not reported by the committee within six days of publication, it will be discharged. After the Speaker reconvenes the House within two days of receiving certification, a committee may be discharged from further consideration of a joint resolution if supported by 218 Members of the House of Representatives within 6 calendar days of the Federal Register notice. After a committee is discharged from considering a joint resolution, a motion can be made in the House to proceed with the resolution within 3 calendar days. All points of order against the motion are waived, and the previous question is ordered on the motion without interruption. The joint resolution shall be considered as read and the previous question shall be ordered on its passage without debate, except for two hours of debate controlled by the proponent and opponent. Reconsideration of the vote on passage is not allowed. The joint resolution shall be considered as read and the previous question shall be ordered on its passage without debate. Reconsideration of the vote on passage is not allowed. In the Senate, an expedited procedure is followed for reconvening and reporting on the resolution. The committee may be discharged from further consideration of a joint resolution if not reported within 6 days after Federal Register notice, upon a petition supported by 40 Senate Members. The petition must be filed within 6 days of the notice. When a committee reports or is discharged from a joint resolution, a motion can be made to proceed to its consideration. All points of order are waived, and the motion is not amendable or subject to postponement. When a motion to proceed to the consideration of a joint resolution is agreed to, it becomes the unfinished business of the Senate. Consideration of the joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing it. When a motion to proceed to the consideration of a joint resolution is agreed to, it becomes the unfinished business of the Senate. Consideration is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing it. A motion to limit debate is in order and not debatable. An amendment, motion to postpone, proceed to other business, or recommit the joint resolution is not allowed. The vote on passage occurs immediately after the conclusion of consideration, with a single quorum call if requested. When a joint resolution is considered in the Senate, rulings of the chair on procedure are final without debate. The resolution cannot be amended in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. Coordination with the other house is required before passing the resolution. When a joint resolution is considered in the Senate, rulings of the chair on procedure are final without debate. The resolution cannot be amended in either house. If one house receives a joint resolution from the other, it supplants the original resolution during the vote on passage. If the Senate fails to act, the House resolution is entitled to expedited floor procedures. When a joint resolution is considered in the Senate, rulings of the chair on procedure are final without debate. The resolution cannot be amended in either house. If one house receives a joint resolution from the other, it supplants the original resolution during the vote on passage. Debate on a veto message in the Senate under this section shall be 1 hour equally divided between the majority and minority leaders or their designees. This paragraph is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate and House of Representatives. The joint resolution process in Congress allows for final rulings on procedure in the Senate without debate. The resolution cannot be amended and supersedes other rules in the respective Houses. Each House retains the right to change its rules regarding procedures. The amendment made by section 2 will be effective on January 1, 2013.
